Title: Reconceptualising Third World Women: A Literary Theoretical Framework for Redressing Western Feminist Narratives

Abstract

The present study critically examines the representation of Third World women within Western feminist discourses and proposes a literary theoretical framework to challenge and transform these narratives. Drawing on postcolonial theory, intersectionality, and transnational feminism, the following paper argues for a more nuanced understanding of Third World women that moves beyond reductive stereotypes and affirms their agency, diversity, and complexity. Through a rigorous analysis of influential Western feminist texts, this research exposes the perpetuation of harmful narratives surrounding Third World women and calls for alternative ways of knowing and engaging with women's experiences across the globe. Ultimately, the paper contributes to a more just and inclusive feminist project that fosters solidarity across borders and acknowledges the dynamic and interconnected nature of women's struggles worldwide.

Introduction

In the contemporary lexicon, the term 'Third World' invokes an image of nations that are mired in economic disparities, political turbulence, and social upheaval. Nevertheless, such a monolithic understanding of these regions obscures the multifaceted realities of their inhabitants, particularly women. Consequently, Western feminist scholarship has often reproduced a homogenising discourse that marginalises and disempowers Third World women by constructing them as passive victims of their oppressive circumstances. Chandra Talpade Mohanty's pioneering work, "Under Western Eyes: Feminist Scholarship and Colonial Discourses" (1988), laid the groundwork for challenging these essentialist and ethnocentric narratives. Drawing inspiration from Mohanty's critique, this study ventures to propose a literary theoretical framework that addresses the shortcomings of Western feminist depictions of Third World women.

In this pursuit, the following paper is divided into four sections. Firstly, a literature review will delineate the historical context of Western feminist engagement with Third World women and scrutinise the problematic nature of such encounters. Next, the methodology employed for conducting this research will be explicated, highlighting the relevance of textual analysis and critical discourse analysis in examining prominent feminist texts. The subsequent section will delve into the proposed literary theoretical framework, encompassing postcolonial theory, intersectionality, and transnational feminism, to better comprehend and represent Third World women's experiences. Finally, the paper will conclude with a reflection on the potential of this framework to foster more inclusive and equitable feminist discourses in the future.

Literature Review

The legacy of Western feminism, particularly within academia, is rife with instances of intellectual encounters that have distorted the experiences of Third World women. In her pioneering essay, Mohanty (1988) investigates this phenomenon, arguing that Western feminist scholarship often constructs Third World women as objects of study in ways that perpetuate colonial discourses. She contends that such scholarship fails to recognise the agency of Third World women, portraying them as passive victims in need of Western feminist intervention. This intellectual stance relegates Third World women to the margins of feminist inquiry, exacerbating their subjugation within a global context. Mohanty's critique underscores the necessity of reassessing and reimagining Western feminist engagement with women from developing countries.

In a similar vein, Inderpal Grewal and Caren Kaplan (1994) locate the roots of Western feminist ethnocentrism within the broader colonial project, asserting that it has always been inextricably linked to imperial ambitions. They argue that the production of knowledge about Third World women serves to validate Western intervention in these regions, perpetuating an unequal power dynamic that benefits the First World. Building on these observations, Uma Narayan (1997) interrogates the tendency of Western feminists to subscribe to "cultural imperialism," imposing their beliefs and values onto other cultures in a manner that reproduces colonial relations of domination and subordination. Collectively, these works demonstrate a pressing need for decolonising feminist scholarship and moving towards more complex and nuanced portrayals of Third World women.

Methodology

To substantiate the claims put forth in the preceding section, this study employs a qualitative research design involving the critical analysis of seminal Western feminist texts that engage with Third World women. Adopting a discourse analytic approach, it highlights the continuities and ruptures within these works that engender hegemonic narratives about women from developing countries. Consequently, this analysis will focus on the way Western feminist scholarship frames the experiences of Third World women, scrutinising the assumptions, prejudices, and erasures that inform such renderings.

Theoretical Framework

In response to the aforementioned critiques, this paper offers a literary theoretical framework to facilitate a more holistic understanding of Third World women's experiences. This framework comprises three salient theoretical perspectives: postcolonial theory, intersectionality, and transnational feminism.

1. Postcolonial Theory

Derived from the intellectual tradition that seeks to dismantle colonial structures and legacies, postcolonial theory encompasses diverse theoretical and methodological approaches to interrogate and decolonise Western-centric paradigms of knowledge (Bhabha, 1994; Said, 1978; Spivak, 1988). Within this framework, postcolonial theory offers a means to challenge the power dynamics embedded in Western feminist discourses and to foreground the complex subjectivities of Third World women.

2. Intersectionality

Coined by legal scholar Kimberlé Crenshaw (1989), intersectionality underscores the multiple and interlocking systems of oppression that shape the lives of women across diverse contexts. This framework illuminates the ways in which Third World women's experiences are intricately entwined with factors such as race, class, caste, and religion. By unearthing these layered intersections, scholars can develop a more nuanced understanding of the unique challenges faced by women in developing countries.

3. Transnational Feminism

Transnational feminism offers a transformative approach to feminist inquiry that transcends the confines of the nation-state (Grewal & Kaplan, 1994; Mohanty, 2003). Through the lens of transnationalism, feminist scholars can foster a sense of solidarity that acknowledges the interconnectedness of women's struggles worldwide. Adopting this perspective can sharpen the collective capacities to dismantle the systems of power that oppress women both inside and outside the Global South.

Conclusion

In summation, this paper contends that the representation of Third World women within Western feminist scholarship necessitates a reckoning with the historical and political implications of such discourse. By deploying a robust literary theoretical framework grounded in postcolonial theory, intersectionality, and transnational feminism, scholars can forge a more equitable and inclusive approach to understanding the diverse experiences of women across the globe. Ultimately, a concerted effort towards transforming these narratives will lay the foundation for a more just and sustainable feminist project that transcends geographical, cultural, and ideological boundaries.

This scholarly investigation delves into the epistemological ramifications of Western feminist portrayals of Third World women, employing a literary theoretical lens. An examination of selected non-fiction essays and academic literature reveals an issue fraught with ideological biases, inscription of hegemonic norms, and marginalisation of subaltern voices. By employing critical literary theory, including postcolonial studies, feminist theory, and intersectional theory, this paper illuminates the problematic implications of Western feminist discourse and its representations of Third World women.

Introduction

Undeniably, numerous geopolitical divides have pervaded the complex matrix of international relations since the onset of twentieth-century postcolonial globalisation. These fissures are often manifested in the form of racial, economic, and gendered disparities, among others. Nevertheless, one of the most pernicious and continuing of these socio-political cleavages is found in the categorisation of nations into First, Second, and Third Worlds. Notwithstanding its origin as a Cold War conceptualisation, this taxonomy has endured well into the twenty-first century and continues to demarcate the world into privileged and underprivileged spaces.

It is within this context that the present essay embarks on an exploration of Western feminist portrayals of women from Third World countries. From this vantage point, the enquiry shifts from a traditional geopolitical analysis to an epistemological enquiry concerned with the knowledge production and dissemination of ideas about Third World women by Western feminists. Additionally, the paper elucidates how these representations contribute to the marginalisation of said women and perpetuates hegemonic practices within the global feminist discourse.

Theoretical Framework

To adequately investigate this domain, the study incorporates a tripartite theoretical framework comprising postcolonial studies, feminist theory, and intersectional theory. Postcolonial studies provide an apt methodological tool, as it is primarily concerned with the power dynamics and hegemonic systems that emerge from and perpetuate colonial legacies. Similarly, feminist theory offers insights into the ways gender relations intersect with other axes of inequality and domination, while intersectional theory allows for the simultaneity of oppressions to be unravelled and understood in relation to one another.

Feminist theory provides a complementary perspective to the postcolonial critique of Western feminist representations of Third World women. This academic investigation has unveiled the epistemological, ideological, and political underpinnings of Western feminist representations of Third World women. Utilising a robust, multi-layered theoretical framework, the research has demonstrated the complexities, and at times, insidious nature of knowledge production and distribution in relation to women from developing nations. In doing so, it has shed light on the pressing impetus for rupturing and reconstructing the hegemonic discourses that continue to marginalise and disempower Third World women.

Although the terrain remains fraught with contestations, the paper offers both theoretical and practical insights into the ways hegemonic power structures can be confronted and dismantled. Consequently, it invites an ongoing dialogue among scholars and activists to continuously question, examine and transform the epistemological foundations of feminist thought, ultimately pursuing a more inclusive, equitable, and compassionate world for all.

Said's seminal opus Orientalism provides an entirely innovative analytical framework through which one can scrutinise the hegemonic power relations that have historically shaped Western representations of non-Western cultures. Initially devised to encompass the countries comprising three distinct continents—Africa, Asia, and Latin America—emerged as a direct result of Cold War political alliances, which compelled said territories to opt for one of two overarching geopolitical factions: a capitalist or NATO First World or an ostensibly communist Second World bloc led by the Soviet Union. In his seminal work, Said expounds upon the intricate power dynamics embedded within the use of language to "other" and hegemonize various cultures and societies, ultimately equating such practices with colonialist ventures that ultimately seek to subjugate and dominate the purported "Orient". Therefore, the propensity for Western feminists to reduce the multifarious lived experiences of Third World women to a seemingly monolithic and homogenous entity can be seen as an extension of the colonialist enterprise.

Equally indispensable to the broader critical discourse interrogating the term "Third World women" is the rich theoretical contribution of Spivak, whose subaltern theory provides an incisive critique of the ways in which Western feminism co-opts, appropriates, and ostensibly champions the voices of marginalized and underrepresented women whilst simultaneously reinforcing the systemic underpinnings of their disenfranchisement. Furthermore, by calling attention to these issues, it is incumbent upon feminists, scholars, and activists alike to continuously strive towards a more decolonized, inclusive, and egalitarian vision of feminism that eschews hegemonic power dynamics and centers the diverse lived experiences of women around the world.

An Interrogation: Connotations and Implications Associated with "Third World Women"

Primarily, one must consider how the historical roots and subsequent evolution of the phrase "Third World" intertwine with the broader implications it now bears. Etymologically, as alluded to in the introduction, the term was conceived and utilized during the Cold War era, signifying countries that remained unaligned with the predominant capitalist and communist blocs. In this vein, it is essential to inquire whether Western feminist discourse unintentionally reinforces harmful stereotypes surrounding Third World women through its deployment of this term.

Delving into an examination of Western feminist literature, one encounters several instances where Third World women are depicted as victims of societal norms, patriarchal customs, and religious mandates. This negative stereotyping of Third-World countries is also evident in the way Western feminists have portrayed Third-World women. Therefore, for this paper, the term “Third World women” will be used in the manner Western feminists employ it in their written works.

Negotiating Linguistic Hierarchies: An Investigation into Western Feminist Depictions of Third World Women

Introduction

Eschewing customary linguistic constructions such as "The," "These," and "This," the employment of a potent and nuanced lexicon serves to unveil hitherto unexplored avenues for a thorough analysis of the term "Third World women." As utilized by Western feminists within their literary corpus, this term demands exploration through the employment of diverse literary theoretical frameworks, underpinned by the insights offered by esteemed critics. The crux of this paper revolves around examining the extent to which Western feminist discourse perpetuates detrimental stereotypes of Third World women, contributing, perhaps unintentionally, to their ongoing marginalization and oppression.

Dissecting the Semantics: Tracing the Historical and Connotative Implications of "Third World Women"

A primary aspect to consider is how the historical origin and subsequent evolution of the term "Third World" intertwine with its contemporary implications. As mentioned in the introduction, the term emerged during the Cold War era as a descriptor for countries that were not aligned with either the capitalist First World nor the communist Second World blocs. However, as geopolitical landscapes have metamorphosed over time, the term has expanded to encompass countries experiencing development challenges, chiefly located in Africa, Asia, and Latin America. These countries often grapple with economic and social underdevelopment, political turmoil, restricted access to education and healthcare, and elevated poverty rates.

In conjunction with this, Said's (1978) groundbreaking work "Orientalism" offers invaluable insights into the significant role language and representation play as instruments of power. Extending from Said's (1978) argument, one may contend that using the term "Third World" when referring to these nations inadvertently perpetuates a perception of hierarchical development, thereby fostering prejudicial attitudes against them. Bearing this in mind, it becomes pertinent to question whether Western feminist discourse, through its use of the term "Third World women," unwittingly bolsters harmful stereotypes about these individuals.

Third World Women: The Implications of Representations in Western Feminist Literature

Exploring the realm of Western feminist literature, one is confronted with several instances wherein Third World women are portrayed as victims of cultural practices, patriarchal norms, and religious strictures. Numerous critics have challenged the validity of such portrayals, arguing that instead of amplifying the voices and concerns of Third World women, these representations often result in their silencing and objectification (Mohanty, 1988; Narayan, 1997).

Mohanty's (1988) critical analysis of Western feminist scholarship on Third World women argues that these works frequently exhibit an ethnocentric bias. By assuming homogeneity among Third World women and pathologizing their experiences as symbolizing patriarchal subjugation, Western feminists effectively preclude the possibility of Third World women voicing their distinct struggles and victories. Applying a Poststructuralist framework, one can illuminate the discursive practices that engender such representations – practices that, according to Foucault (1972), serve to reinforce societal hierarchies and power relations.

Additionally, Spivak's (1988) seminal work "Can the Subaltern Speak?" sheds light on the asymmetrical relationship between Third World women and their Western feminist counterparts. Proposing that the subaltern – marginalized individuals positioned at the periphery of society – remain inaudible, Spivak (1988) suggests that attempts by Western feminists to represent the plight of Third World women inevitably result in the latter's further alienation and disempowerment. Such observations call for an exploration of alternative modes of representation that may promote increased cultural and individual sensitivity.

Forging a New Paradigm: Embracing Intersectionality and Empowerment

In reevaluating Western feminist discourse's treatment of Third World women, it is essential to recognize the recent strides made by scholars advocating for a more inclusive and empowering approach. Lorde's (1984) concept of double jeopardy – emphasizing the compounded impact of racism and sexism experienced by women of color – provides an invaluable framework for understanding the complex nature of oppression encountered by Third World women. Similarly, Crenshaw's (1989) notion of intersectionality underscores the importance of considering multiple interconnected social, economic, and political factors shaping the unique lived experiences of these individuals. By acknowledging the distinct realities navigated by Third World women, scholars can work towards dismantling pernicious stereotypes and validating these women's agency in charting their destinies.

Conclusion

In conclusion, a conscientious examination utilizing a diverse array of theoretical frameworks uncovers the potential for Western feminist discourse to perpetuate stereotypes and contribute to the marginalization of Third World women. Drawing inspiration from Said's (1978) perspective on language as a conduit of power, Mohanty's (1988) critique of homogenizing portrayals of Third World women, and Spivak's (1988) skepticism regarding the subaltern's capacity to be heard, this paper endeavors to emphasize the urgent need for critical reflection and revision within the sphere of representation. By incorporating intersectionality and empowerment into their approaches, scholars may work to afford Third World women their rightful agency, discarding archaic narratives that limit and confine their potential.

Eurocentrism is generally defined as a way of thinking that places European culture, history, and values at the center of the world while ignoring or downplaying the contributions of other cultures and civilizations. One could argue that Europe, more specifically Western Europe or “the West,” is often used as a universal symbol that presupposes the superiority of European cultural values over those of non-European societies. Eurocentric narratives have a recurring inclination to overlook and undervalue the contributions of non-Western cultures. Such accounts distort non-European histories and legacies by viewing them solely through European or western perspectives. In his seminal text Orientalism (1979), Edward Said, a Palestinian critic, asserts that “European culture gained in strength and identity by setting itself off against the Orient as a sort of surrogate and even underground self.” (3) This dichotomy between the West and the East often presents the West as a modern, flowing territory and the East as a static, archaic region. Some Third-World feminists have also sought to deconstruct how the concept of feminism has been postulated and understood within the Western feminist tradition and to challenge the assumptions and biases that have shaped this tradition. By doing so, they have sought to create more inclusive and intersectional approaches to feminist thought and activism that are tuned to women’s diverse experiences and needs worldwide. They aim to understand women’s struggles in connection with historical, cultural, economic, religious, geographical and political settings, opposing the idea that women are one homogeneous, generic and victimized singular entity and an undifferentiated other. They reject the notion that Western women can speak for ‘other’ women without having experienced their life and culture. Moreover, they have adopted diverse strategies and methodologies to expose and challenge Eurocentric narratives.
In light of the above, this paper aims to examine the role played by Western feminists in postcolonial endeavours aimed at liberating and supporting Third-World women, as addressed by Third-World feminists. It notes that one of the barriers to forging a common sisterhood is the difference in how they represent themselves and Third World women.
Under Western Eyes
In “Under Western Eyes: Feminist Scholarship and Colonial Discourses” (1984), Chandra Mohanty critiques the way in which Western feminist scholarship has historically approached the experiences and issues of women in non-Western cultures. Mohanty argues that this scholarship often essentializes and homogenizes the experiences of these women, reducing them to a monolithic and victimized group, and ignores the diversity and agency of these individuals. This homogenization is not based on “biological” factors but rather on “sociological and anthropological universals” that often treat women as a singular group due to the perceived “sameness of their oppression.” (Mohanty 65) By failing to consider the complexities and subtleties involved in these experiences adequately, Western feminist research creates a distorted and oversimplified “image of the average third-world woman.” (65) 
In her analysis, Chandra Mohanty examines how the creation of a unitary, homogenized image of non-Western women in discourse serves to exercise orientalist power. According to Mohanty, this monolithic representation of non-Western women is contrasted with the “self-representation” of Western feminists, resulting in the erasure of non-Western women’s “historical and political agency.” (Liddle and Rai, 1998, p. 500) Western feminists are depicted as the true subjects” of this counter-history, while non-Western women are reduced to the “debilitating generality” of their “object” status. (Mohanty 79) The “average Third World woman” is portrayed as “ignorant, poor, uneducated, traditional, religious, domesticated, family-oriented, and victimized,” while Western women are depicted as “educated, modern, and in control of their bodies and sexualities with the “freedom” to make their own decisions.” (65) The construction of the Third world women as Other and oppressed beings thus implicitly demands from First world women to be their saviors and voices. Since she cannot save and represent herself in the vicious circle of oppression, she needs to be represented. Moreover, since these Third world women are “identical and interchangeable” therefore, “knowing one woman, what she needs, and how to fulfill those needs, is sufficient for the development expert to know and develop all other third world women.” (Wood, 2001, p. 431)
In her work, Mohanty identifies six dominant feminist discourses that contribute to the portrayal of “Third World women” as a unified and homogenous group. These discourses depict “Third World women” as victims of male violence, colonial oppression, family systems, development processes, and religious ideologies. These representations often position “Third World women” as passive and vulnerable, lacking agency and independence.






      



 


Women as victims of male violence
The portrayal of victimhood of women in Western feminist discourse often centers on sexual oppression and male violence, with issues such as female genital mutilation being frequently cited, particularly in African and Middle Eastern societies. While instances of male violence against women exist, reducing all “Third World women” to passive victims and all men to violent perpetrators fails to consider the complexities and specificities of individual societies and their systems of power. This oversimplification creates a homogenous group of women who are seen as solely suffering from male violence and a monolithic group of men who are seen as violent. Instead, it is essential to carefully analyze and understand male violence within these societies in order to work more effectively toward change. “Sisterhood cannot be assumed on the basis of gender; it must be forged in concrete, historical and political practice and analysis.” (Mohanty 67)
Women as universal dependents
In this discussion, Mohanty highlights the common portrayal of Third World Women in Western scholarship as universal dependents in both political and economic terms. Mohanty cites the depiction of African, Vietnamese, and Black American women as examples of this generalization. This generalization often involves portraying these diverse groups as homogenous and suffering from the same forms of oppression due to their ethnicity, gender, and class. Mohanty argues that this approach assumes that men and women are already established as “sexual-political subjects” prior to engaging in social relationships, and as a result, analyses of the impacts of factors such as “colonialism, labor organization, and kinship structures” on women are flawed. This is because these analyses are based on the assumption that women are already defined as a group due to shared dependencies, ultimately stemming from their “gender.” (Mohanty 68)
Married women as victims of colonial process
Western feminist scholars often depict married “Third World women,” such as Bemba women in Zambia, as uniform victims of colonialism. Mohanty criticizes this portrayal as being overly simplistic and lacking in nuance, as it fails to consider the agency and complexity of these women’s lived realities. Instead, Mohanty suggests that a more nuanced approach is needed, one that recognizes the ways in which power relations within kinship structures shape women’s experiences rather than treating them as passive subjects. This approach also acknowledges that women’s identities are not solely defined by their entry into marriage but rather by the various social structures in which they find themselves.
Women and Familial Systems
In this section, the author discusses how kinship structures, such as patriarchal families, may be used to define and construct women’s homogenizing roles and identities within a family and society. This scholarship of assuming a singular, cohesive kinship system that influences the socio-economic status of women is used to portray all Arab and Muslim societies while ignoring the particular “historical and ideological power structures” that shape these societies. (Mohanty 70) When speaking of the “patriarchal family or tribal kinship structure” as the origin of women’s “socio-economic status,” it is again to assume that women are “sexual-political subjects prior to their entry into the family” and thus, the methodology fails to account for the specific practices within the family that construct women as mothers, wives, sisters, etc. (Mohanty, 70) According to Mohanty, it is essential to consider the ways in which kinship structures are used as “ideological practices” that shape gender roles and relations rather than assuming a universal, static system that affects all women in the same way.
Women and Religious Ideologies
There are several limitations to the way that third-world women are often viewed as uniform victims of religion. This approach ignores these women’s unique experiences and identities and simplifies the role of religion, like Islam, to a single unified ideology. Instead, it is essential to recognize that religion, ideology, and economic factors intersect and influence women’s experiences in different societies in complex and diverse ways. This is something that Mohanty has pointed out as being particularly important to consider.
     Women and the Development Process
Western feminist scholars often approach the development of Third World women through a narrow lens, assuming that “development” is synonymous with “economic development” or “economic progress” only. Perdita Huston, for example, argues that development policies in countries like Egypt, Kenya, Sudan, Tunisia, Sri Lanka, and Mexico do not adequately address the needs of women, which she believes “centre around education and training, work and wages, access to health and other services, and political participation and legal rights.” (Mohanty 72) Huston suggests that these needs result from the lack of “sensitive development policies” that “exclude women as a group,” and she proposes that policies that prioritize “training for women field-workers, use women trainees, and encourage women’s cooperatives” would be more effective.(Mohanty 72) However, this approach to development again fails to consider the complexity of the interests and experiences of women from different social classes and cultures and can result in the “colonization of their specific experiences and political interests.” (72) According to Mohanty, Huston’s representation of women in the third world also lacks the acknowledgment of their agency, presenting them as having “needs and problems” but not “choices or the freedom to act.” (72)
Mohanty, therefore, critiques the “assumptions and implicit principles” (64) underlying Western feminist scholarship on non-Western women and calls for a more inclusive approach that recognizes the agency and diversity of these women. She argues that this approach is informed by a colonial discourse that perpetuates the power dynamic between the West and the rest of the world, characterized by a lack of consideration for the specific histories and contexts of non-Western societies and an assumption of Western superiority. This approach is harmful as it reinforces power imbalances and fails to represent the experiences of non-Western women accurately. Mohanty highlights the challenges of constructing a homogenous group, emphasizing that oppression is always contextualized by history, ethnicity, and local social culture and cannot be equated with one another. 
Case of Firdaus in Novel Women at Point Zero
Nawal El Saadawi’s Women at Point Zero (1983) offers an opportunity to explore the portrayal of Firdaus, the central character, through the lens of Mohanty’s critique. The memoir presents a captivating and thought-provoking portrayal of its protagonist, Firdaus, whose identity and experiences are shaped by intersecting power systems, such as patriarchy, colonialism, religion, poverty and capitalism. Through this character, the memoir delves into the complexity and multifaceted nature of the intersecting themes of gender, oppression, violence, religion, race, and class, making it a valuable contribution to the ongoing research on intersectionality in the experiences of women. Rather than presenting Firdaus as a one-dimensional representative of all women in the global South, Women at Point Zero recognizes and emphasizes the individuality and distinctness of her life. The book deconstructs the notion of reductionism by illuminating the intricate interplay of various factors, such as personal history, interpersonal relationships, cultural and societal contexts, and religious beliefs, in shaping Firdaus’s life and experiences rather than attributing the entirety of the narrative to a single element.
Firdaus’ journey is one of resilience and determination in the face of overwhelming adversity. Despite facing sexual abuse, financial hardship, and domestic violence, she remains undaunted in her efforts to break free from the oppressive structures that seek to confine her. Through her actions, Firdaus resists the limiting and dehumanizing expectations placed upon her by various agencies, demonstrating a formidable will to survive and thrive in the face of systemic injustice. In this way, Firdaus not only challenges and subverts the essentialist and stereotypical views of women from the global South as passive and oppressed but also serves as a beacon of hope and inspiration for others who may be struggling to find their own path to freedom and self-determination.
Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) 
Female genital mutilation (FGM), also known as female circumcision, refers to the partial or complete removal of the external female genitalia for non-medical purposes. The practice is commonly found in areas of Africa and the Middle East and is often motivated by cultural, religious, or social beliefs. Western feminists have vociferously decried female genital mutilation (FGM), with Fran Hosken taking a particularly critical stance on the practice. However, Hosken’s perspective on FGM is centred on the idea that it is a harmful, deliberate attempt to deprive women of “sexual pleasure and satisfaction.” (Mohanty 66) While this perspective is certainly valid, it is worth noting that there are many other factors at play when it comes to FGM, including historical, social, traditional, and religious considerations. Ignoring these broader aspects could lead to an incomplete understanding of the problem and potentially ineffective solutions.
The practice of genital mutilation is not simply a matter of gender inequality; a way of controlling women’s sexuality and ensuring that they remain sexually passive and obedient to men. Instead, it is a deeply entrenched and complex issue often rooted in political power dynamics. Its continuation and perpetuation result from a broader social, cultural, and political control system. In the memoir, Firdaus poignantly illustrates the devastating impact of genital mutilation on her psyche, recounting the trauma and agony of the procedure during her youth and the ongoing physical and emotional suffering it has inflicted upon her. She recalls the brutal incident with great distress, recounting how her mother “bought a woman who was carrying a small knife or maybe a razor blade” to “cut off a piece of flesh from between her thighs,” an act that left Firdaus inconsolable as she, “cried all night.” (13) Firdaus elucidates the political and cultural traditions that undergird female genital mutilation (FGM). This pernicious and intrusive practice is often perpetuated under the pretext that it is a crucial rite of passage to attain the status of a ‘respectable’ and ‘proper’ woman. Conversely, those who do not undergo FGM are frequently ‘ostracized’ and ‘marginalised’ within their communities. She asserts this belief by stating that, “A virtuous woman was not supposed to complain about her husband. Her duty was perfect obedience.” (44) The practice is a deeply ingrained aspect of collective experience that holds significant cultural, social, and economic value. It is considered a crucial element in the development and expression of womanhood and a source of ‘pride’ and ‘honour’ for families. Given the centrality of this practice to social identity within the community, it is understandable that Firdaus’ parents would view her infibulation as a necessary step in preserving her perceived purity and, by extension, her value as a potential spouse in the marriage market. The scene is described in the memoir as 
Firdaus’ Aunt to her Husband: If my uncle (Sheikh Mahmoud) marries Firdaus she will have a good life with him, and he can find in her an obedient wife, who will serve him and relieve his loneliness.
Husband: Do you think Sheikh Mahmoud will welcome the idea?
Aunt: If I speak to him, I am sure he will agree. I intend to ask him for a big dowry.
Husband: How much?
Aunt: A hundred pounds or perhaps even two hundred if he has the money. (36-37)
Therefore, due to the lack of agency and the stronghold of tradition, many girls come to view circumcision as a normal and necessary aspect of life, internalizing the justifications provided for its continuation. (Althaus, 1997, p. 132) Women at Point Zero, thus, situates the practice of genital mutilation within the broader context of power dynamics and systemic oppression that significantly impact the life experiences of its protagonist, Firdaus.
Kinship and Religious Structures
…Every single man I did get to know filled me with but one desire: to lift my hand and bring it smashing down on his face. But because I am a woman, I have never had the courage to lift my hand. And because I am a prostitute, I hid my fear under the layers of make-up (Woman At point zero, p. 10)
The commonly held perception in the Western world is that Muslim societies are inherently patriarchal, with Muslim women facing oppression. The religion of Islam is often erroneously perceived as a patriarchal system that advocates for the subjugation of women. However, Moroccan feminist and sociologist Fatima Mernissi argues that this interpretation is based on a misunderstanding of the Quran and is actually a product of “cultural” and “historical” circumstances rather than an inherent aspect of Muslim societies or the religion itself. While it is true that some societies may exhibit a pervasive attitude of male superiority and female subservience, (Islam and Patriarchy - and Why It’s Important to Understand, 2015) it is problematic to make broad generalizations or stereotypes about the experiences of Muslim women or their religion. She asserts that “Islam isn’t patriarchal , but patriarchy has been heavily involved in the history of the middle east, and have subsequently seeped into the ways Muslims practice their faith.” (Islam and Patriarchy - and Why It’s Important to Understand) 
Moreover, it is important to consider the way that this is not just a problem of religion but also of ‘power’ and ‘representation.’ One can see this as an act of violence that is not an aberration but rather an inevitable result of patriarchal systems, where men with religious authority, use it to maintain and justify power over others and this is not limited to Islam but a problem of how all religions can be manipulated in such ways. As Michel Foucault has astutely noted, power is not concentrated in the hands of a select few but rather is pervasive and operates through various institutions, including religion. Thus, it is not simply a question of religious doctrine but rather an intricate web of power relations that must be examined and dismantled to address this phenomenon. The character Firdaus in the text highlights this ideology through an encounter with her uncle’s wife, who reveals that her husband, a “respected sheikh well-versed in the teachings of religion, often beats her.” Firdaus initially finds this difficult to reconcile, but the uncle’s wife clarifies that “men who are well-versed in their religion often use religious precepts as justification for such punishment.” (44) This serves as a representation of Michel Foucault’s idea of “knowledge as power,” where men are utilizing religious knowledge as a means of domination.
Through the portrayal of a Firdaus’ journey in Woman at Point Zero, El Saadawi deconstructs the oversimplified and monolithic image of Arab and Muslim societies as strictly patriarchal, instead revealing the complex social and cultural practices that shape the identities and experiences of women in these societies. By delving into the historical and ideological power structures that have contributed to the portrayal of women in these cultures as oppressed, the work offers a more nuanced and comprehensive perspective on the realities of women’s lives in Arab and Muslim societies.
Firdaus, as a character, represents the fluid and multifaceted nature of personal identity. Through her encounters with a range of social structures, including family, religion, relationships with men, and the broader societal context, we see how her sense of self is constantly evolving and being shaped. While the institution of marriage may play a role in this process, it is not the sole determinant of Firdaus’s identity. Rather, the cumulative impact of all the different social structures she engages with ultimately shapes her sense of self and her place in the world. 
Firdaus’ upbringing is indelibly shaped by the dynamics within her family first. Born into poverty and raised by a neglectful and abusive father, Firdaus suffered from trauma and instability during her childhood, which continued to impact her throughout her life. Furthermore, the submissive nature of her mother and the expectations placed on her daughters to follow traditional gender roles, with men as the dominant figures in the household and women as inferior and subservient, contribute to the perpetuation of these harmful dynamics. The maternal figure is expected to prioritize her spouse’s needs above her own and to support and service her husband and children rather than pursue her own aspirations and desires. The traditional family structures are used to reinforce the subordinate position of women. Firdaus narrates in the following manner
My father never went to bed without supper, no matter what happened. Sometimes when there was no food at home, we would all go to bed with empty stomachs. But he would never fail to have a meal. My mother would hide his food from us at the bottom of one of the holes in the oven. He would sit eating alone while we watched him. (pp. 18-19)
Firdaus’ relationships with men throughout the novel illustrate the power dynamics at play within kinship structures. She is frequently in positions of vulnerability and powerlessness in her relationships with men, who are often abusive and exploitative towards her. The arranged marriage between Firdaus and Sheikh Mahmoud illustrates the impact of kinship structures on the construction of gender roles and relationships within the family unit. In this society, the traditional kinship structure dictates that marriage serves as a means of achieving ‘economic’ and ‘social stability,’ with women expected to be submissive and obedient to their husbands. This reinforces traditional gender roles and power imbalances within the marriage, with Sheikh Mahmoud occupying a position of superiority and Firdaus expected to adhere to his expectations and wishes. This is illustrated in the following lines spoken by Firdaus
On one occasion he (Sheikh Mahmoud) hit me all over with his shoe. My face and body became swollen and bruised. So, I left the house and went to my uncle. But my uncle told me that all husbands beat their wives and my uncle’s wife added that her husband often beat her…. A virtuous woman was not supposed to complain about her husband. Her duty was perfect obedience. (44)
From an early age, Firdaus and her siblings were at the mercy of their father and the other males in their family, who treated them as mere assets to be traded or sold for their own benefit. This is poignantly captured in her words, “My father, a poor peasant farmer, who could neither read nor write, knew very few things in life. How to grow crops, how to sell a buffalo poisoned by his enemy before it died, how to exchange his virgin daughter for a dowry when there was still time… (12) This behaviour illustrates the unfortunate reality of the subjugation of ‘female agency’ and ‘self-determination’ within familial dynamics while perpetuating the pernicious perception of women as mere commodities to be bartered and exchanged. Therefore, these power imbalances within kinship structures are used as “ideological practices” to reinforce traditional gender roles and inequalities, and they often serve to oppress and discriminate against women.
After being forced into marriage at a young age and enduring the subsequent subjugation and maltreatment inflicted by her spouse, the protagonist mustered the fortitude to break free from the shackles of domestic tyranny and seek her own autonomy. This courageous act, however, led her to a life of destitution and further exploitation as a prostitute. Firdaus’ physical being is utilized in a commoditized manner, with her being subjected to constant exploitation for the gain and satisfaction of others. Her existence is reduced to a mere object to be purchased and traded by individuals known as pimps, which obligate her to engage in sexual acts with various clients daily. Furthermore, she is frequently subjected to acts of physical violence as a means of coercion to comply with the whims of both her pimps and clients and is faced with punishment if she fails to do so. Firdaus narrates 
Sharifa said to me one day, “Neither Bayoumi, nor any one of his cronies realized your worth, because you failed to value yourself highly enough. A man doesn’t know a woman’s value, Firdaus. She is the one who determines her value. The higher you price yourself, the more he will realise what you are relay worth, and be prepared to pay with the means at his disposal.” (54) 
Woman at Point Zero by Nawal El Saadawi thus challenges the stereotype of Arab and Muslim societies as inherently patriarchal by showing the complexities of social and cultural practices that shape the identities and experiences of women. The character of Firdaus represents the fluid and multifaceted nature of personal identity, shaped by a range of social structures, including family, religion, and societal context. The portrayal of patriarchal systems in the text highlights the manipulation of religion to justify power and domination.
Conclusion
In Woman at Point Zero, the protagonist, Firdaus, is a powerful example of the complexities and nuances of the experiences of non-Western women. Through Firdaus’s story, the novel showcases the importance of an inclusive approach that recognizes the agency and diversity of non-Western women. This approach, as advocated by feminist scholar Chandra Talpade Mohanty, considers the specific histories and contexts of their societies in order to represent their experiences accurately.
The novel reveals how Firdaus’ experiences of oppression are deeply rooted in her specific historical, ethnic, and cultural context and cannot be fully understood or represented through a universalized idea of the ‘oppression of women’. The reader comes to understand how societal structures such as labour division, class, and gender roles contribute to and perpetuate the oppression of non-Western women. It is important to consider these structures within their specific cultural contexts, as they can differ greatly from those found in Western societies.
 It highlights the complexities and nuances of these experiences and makes it clear that a one-size-fits-all approach to understanding and representing the experiences of non-Western women is not sufficient.

Abstract
Postmodern and postcolonial feminists criticize Western feminist scholarship for its tendency to assume the experiences of Third World women are universally and essentially the same, ignoring the diversity and complexity of their lives. To better understand and give voice to the variety of experiences among Third World women, these feminists challenge misleading stereotypes depicting them as helpless, submissive, and oppressed. They emphasize the need to recognize how cultural customs, language, history, education, family dynamics, societal values, religion, racial identity, social class, politics, and economic status shape the lives and experiences of Third World women. In this paper, we explore the ideas of Chandra Talpade Mohanty, a leading postcolonial feminist scholar, and analyze the novel Women at Point Zero to illustrate the multitude of factors that influence the lives and experiences of Third World women. Through this analysis, we challenge Eurocentric narratives, expose their limitations, and demonstrate how the character of Firdaus in the novel confronts essentialist and stereotypical views of women from the global South as passive and oppressed.

Keywords: Postmodern feminism, Third-world women, Essentialism, Stereotyping, Intersectionality.
 
Introduction

Eurocentrism is a thought process that prioritizes European culture, history, and values; often overlooking or undervaluing the contributions of non-Western cultures. This perspective fosters the belief that Western civilization is superior, a notion that is often reinforced through various forms of discourse, including history, literature, and art. In his seminal text, Orientalism, Edward Said contends that the West's portrayal of the Orient is heavily biased and serves to further its own dominance. However, Said's analysis does not explicitly address gender as a factor in constructing these narratives. This paper seeks to build upon Said's argument by examining the role of gender and imperialism in European discourse on colonized societies, specifically the idea of rescuing and civilizing women to justify and reinforce imperial power. By considering the intersection of gender and imperialism, this paper provides a more nuanced and comprehensive understanding of how Western narratives shape the perception of the Orient.

Discussion

Third World women, in Western feminist discourse, are often presented as a homogenous group with the same issues and needs as women in the West. Postcolonial feminists work to resist these universalizing tendencies by understanding women's struggles in relation to historical, cultural, economic, religious, geographical, and political settings. Chandra Mohanty critiques the Western feminist scholarship, arguing that it fails to consider the complexities involved in the experiences of non-Western women and thus creates a distorted and oversimplified image of them.

In Woman at Point Zero, the protagonist, Firdaus, challenges essentialist and stereotypical views through her experiences and the intersection of various factors that shape her life. The novel deconstructs the essentialist view of women, showcasing the complexities and multilayered experiences that non-Western women face. Through the story of Firdaus, the novel demonstrates the importance of considering the specific historical, ethnic, cultural, and social contexts in representing the experiences of non-Western women, contrary to the assumption of homogeneity and universality.

Conclusion

Acknowledging the diverse and complex realities of Third World women is essential in challenging Eurocentric narratives and stereotypes that have shaped Western feminist scholarship for years. By understanding the multitude of factors that influence non-Western women's experiences, we can develop a more inclusive and intersectional understanding of feminism and work towards a more equitable world. The analysis of the novel Women at Point Zero in this paper supports Chandra Talpade Mohanty's arguments and reshapes the understanding of Third World women, presenting them as individuals with unique experiences and identities rather than a homogenous group.
